_exec_summary.SummaryText:
January 2021 Correction: 



On 1/1/2021, Dow AgroSciences, LLC changed it's legal name to Corteva Agriscience LLC.  Legal ownership will remain the same (same tax ID # also). The facility and owner name has been updated in CDX.









April 2020 General Executive Summary for Dow AgroSciences, LLC Midland Operations 



Revisions to the Plan: 



Revisions to the October 30th, 2019 plan are being submitted on April 22nd, 2020 for the following reasons:



Removal of Regulated Substances:



Removed Chlorine, Anhydrous HCl, Phosphorus Trichloride and Phosphorus Oxychloride from 1028 since the previous processes at the plant have been shut down and cleaned out.  They have blown out the pipelines within their block limits and installed blind flanges to the site header for Chlorine and Anhydrous HCl on October 25th, 2019. The plant sent the last of the PCl3 and POCl3 off in a waste trailer on March 9th, 2020. They are no longer using these chemicals at their facility.



Added Non-Applicability Document for New Process: 



The 1028 plant is starting up a new production process, Spinetoram in late summer this year.  The process will have two RMP regulated chemicals Hydrogen and Ethylene, however both will be below the threshold limit of 10,000 lbs. The plant will only have a maximum of 550 lbs of Hydrogen and 100 lbs of Ethylene inside it's block limits at a time. 



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



Dow AgroSciences, LLC Midland Operations is strongly committed to employee, public and environmental safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by a comprehensive accidental release prevention program that covers areas such as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the processes at the facility.  Appropriate controls are implemented to prevent possible releases of regulated substances.  If a release were to occur, highly trained emergency response personnel are on hand to control and mit

igate the effects of the release.  The facility also coordinates with the City of Midland Fire Department and Midland LEPC which can provide additional emergency response expertise.



Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled



Dow AgroSciences, LLC Midland Operations primary activity is chemical manufacturing, including agricultural and specialty chemicals.  There are three (3) covered processes, seven (7) programs and six (6) regulated substances present at the stationary source.  

The regulated substances are listed below.  



Regulated Substances:



Ammonia (anhydrous)

Chlorine

Crotonaldehyde [2-butenal]

Dimethylamine

Sulfur dioxide

Vinylidene chloride



Worst and Alternative Case Scenario Selection



There was one (1) worst case toxic and one (1) worst case flammable scenario reported in this submittal. There are five (5) total alternate cases reported, one of which is a flammable case.  Most of the toxic alternate cases were reported due to that being the only alternate case for the chemical.  No toxic alternate cases for chlorine impacted a population, so the scenario reported for chlorine was the only alternate case that reached an endpoint off-site. The flammable alternate case was chosen due to it being the closest scenario to affect a population based on the location in the plant.  It has the closest scenario with an endpoint to an off-site location. EPA RMP*Comp and MARPLOT were used to evaluate the worst and alternate case scenarios. 



The General Accidental Release Prevention Program



Dow AgroSciences, LLC Midland Operations has taken all the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set out under 40 CFR part 68 of the EPA.  This facility was designed and constructed in accordance with applicable company and governing agency requirements at the time of construction.  Modifications to existing structures are also done in compliance with applicable company standards and gover

ning agency requirements.  Several processes at the facility are subject to the OSHA Process Safety Management standard under 19 CFR 1910.119.  The facility is also subject to EPCRA Section 302 notification requirements.  The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program that is in place at Dow AgroSciences, LLC Midland Operations.



Process Safety Information



Dow AgroSciences, LLC Midland Operations maintains detailed records of safety information that, among other things, describe the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment design associated with all covered processes.  Numerous types of information are available to supplement safety information, including Safety Data Sheets for materials used on site, equipment and engineering design specifications and applicable reactive chemicals testing.



Process Hazard Analysis



Dow AgroSciences, LLC Midland Operations conducts comprehensive studies to ensure that hazards associated with the processes are identified and controlled efficiently.  Findings related to the hazard analyses are addressed in a timely manner.



Operating Procedures



For the purposes of safely conducting activities within the covered processes, Dow AgroSciences, LLC Midland Operations maintains written operating procedures.  These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown and startup after a turnaround.  The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved in the processes.



Training



Dow AgroSciences, LLC Midland Operations has a comprehensive training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating processes are competent in the operating procedures associated with these processes.  Refresher training is provided at least every three years and more frequently as needed.



Mechanical Integrity



Dow AgroSciences, LL

C Midland Operations carries out documented maintenance checks on process equipment to ensure proper operations.  Process equipment examined by these checks includes pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls and pumps.  Maintenance operations are carried out by qualified personnel with training in maintenance practices.  Furthermore, these personnel receive specialized training as needed.  Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.



Management of Change



Written procedures are in place at Dow AgroSciences, LLC Midland Operations to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment and procedures.  Process operators, maintenance personnel or any other employee whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly made aware of and receive training on the modification.



Pre-startup Reviews



Pre-startup safety reviews related to new processes and to modifications of existing processes are conducted as a regular practice at Dow AgroSciences, LLC Midland Operations.  These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment and operating & maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment into operation.



Compliance Audits



Dow AgroSciences, LLC Midland Operations conducts audits on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions set out under the RMP rule and other applicable regulatory requirements are being followed and have been implemented properly. Corrective actions required as a result of the audits are undertaken in a safe and prompt manner.



Incident Investigation



Dow AgroSciences, LLC Midland Operations promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in a release of a regulated substance.  These investigations are undertaken to identify the root causes leading to the incident as well as any correct

ive actions to prevent the release from recurring.  



Employee Participation



Dow AgroSciences, LLC Midland Operations has a written employee participation plan which operates on the premise that process safety management and accident prevention is a team effort.  Company employees are encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues, to attend applicable reviews, and to recommend improvements.  Improvements are solicited and implemented as appropriate.  In addition, employees have access to all information created as part of the facility's implementation of the RMP rule, including information resulting from process hazard analyses in particular. 



Contractors



Dow AgroSciences, LLC Midland Operations hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance, construction and various other activities.  Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of safety performance of the contractor is carried out.  The facility has a strict program for informing contractors of known potential hazards related to the contractor's work and the processes, as well as the procedures for emergency response should an accidental release of a regulated substance occur.  Contractors are also required to inform the facility of any hazards they may introduce or encounter while at the site.



Five-year Accident History



Dow AgroSciences, LLC Midland Operations had no reportable accidents involving RMP chemicals that occurred at this facility within the past five years.



Emergency Response Plan



Dow Chemical ES&S provides emergency response to all Dow Agrosciences, LLC plants and maintains a written emergency response plan to deal with accidental releases of hazardous materials.  The plan documents all aspects of emergency response including adequate first aid and medical treatment, evacuations, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, and post-incident decontamination of affected areas.  The plan is updated as necessary to re

flect any pertinent changes within the processes at the facility that would require a modified emergency response.



The facility works with the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) of Midland County with which the facility emergency plan has been coordinated and verified.



Emergency response equipment is regularly inspected and serviced in order to ensure that it is functioning properly at all times.  



Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Several developments and findings have resulted from the implementation of the various elements of the accidental release prevention program.  Development of Environmental Health and Safety Work Processes, a concentrated Behavior Based Safety effort, and company-wide Environmental Health & Safety goals are some of the major steps taken to improve safety at the Source.  The Michigan Operations Site also works with the Department of Homeland Security to ensure full compliance with the Chemical Facility Anti-Terrorism Standard.
